title: Trauma Score and Injury Severity Score (TRISS)
description: Estimates the probability of survival for trauma patients based on physiological and anatomical parameters. Intended for quality assurance reviews or research to compare actual and predicted outcomes.

parameters.name: age_over_54
parameters.description: Whether patient is over 54 years old

ranges.interpretation: Patient has >90% probability of survival based on TRISS calculation. Continue aggressive trauma care as indicated.
Patient has 75-90% probability of survival. Continue full trauma resuscitation and care.
Patient has 50-75% probability of survival. Aggressive care is warranted with close monitoring.
Patient has 25-50% probability of survival. Consider goals of care discussion while continuing resuscitation efforts.
Patient has <25% probability of survival. Critical condition requiring immediate intervention. Consider resource allocation and family discussion.

references: Boyd CR, Tolson MA, Copes WS. Evaluating trauma care: the TRISS method. Trauma Score and the Injury Severity Score. J Trauma. 1987;27(4):370-378.
Champion HR, Copes WS, Sacco WJ, et al. The Major Trauma Outcome Study: establishing national norms for trauma care. J Trauma. 1990;30(11):1356-65.

Driessen MLS, Sturms LM, Bloemers FW, et al. The detrimental impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on major trauma outcomes in the Netherlands: a comprehensive nationwide study. Ann Surg. 2022;275(2):252-258.
formula: Probability of survival = 1/(1 + e^(-b)) where b = b0 + b1(RTS) + b2(ISS) + b3(A); A = 0 if age â‰¤54, A = 1 if age >54
notes: TRISS is intended for quality assurance and research purposes, not individual patient decision-making
Requires both RTS (Revised Trauma Score) and ISS (Injury Severity Score) calculations
Coefficients differ between blunt and penetrating trauma
Age cutoff of 54 years is based on original study data
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and not as sole predictor
